controller
Class Euclidean

java.lang.Object
  controller.Euclidean
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
 class Euclidean
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

Data about points in 3D space. Each Euclidean is treated like a vector for the purposes of comparison and many geometry functions.

The unitSize of a unit vector is variable.

equals(Object) comparison is done with Double.equals(Object) for each of the three components but another function is available isAbout(Euclidean) to compare another Euclidean within a range determined by Epsilon

Author:
Levi Lindsley

Field Detail

serialVersionUID

private static final long serialVersionUID
Generated serialVersionUID for serialization

See Also:
Constant Field Values

unitSize

private static java.lang.Double unitSize
This is the unitSize of a unit vector, by default it is set as 1.0 but it may be useful when a different scale is required to change this value. There is no change when this value is changed but calls to unitVector() will return scaled to unitSize.

See Also:
changeUnitSize(Double), Epsilon

Epsilon

private static java.lang.Double Epsilon
This is used to compare two Euclidean values using isAbout(Euclidean) Epsilon is used as the bound for determining if the values are equivilent the value for Epsilon may vary per application so a function is avalible to change it.

Epsilon will also auto-scale if unitSize is changed.

See Also:
changeEpsilon(Double), unitSize

planarAngle

Euclidean planarAngle(Euclidean o)
returns Euclidean that represents the angle of this compared to o flattened into three planes, x-z, y-z, x-y.

Parameters:
o - - Euclidean to compare this with
Returns:
Euclidean of flat angles with x = x-z angle, y = y-z angle and z = x-y angle.

length

java.lang.Double length()
Calculates and returns the length of the vector represented by this. The length calculation is done in the standard fashion of sqrt(x*x+y*y+z*z).

Returns:
length of this.

distance

java.lang.Double distance(Euclidean o)
Calculates the linear distance between this and o. The calculation is the length of the vector created by subtracting o from this.

Parameters:
o - - Euclidean to compare this with
Returns:
Distance between this and o as a Double.

scale

private void scale()
Scales a 1.0 unit vector to a unitSize unit vector. Technically scales anything by unitSize.

inverse

Euclidean inverse()
Creates a new Euclidean from the coordinates of this multiplied by -1.

The coordinates of this are unchanged.

Returns:
Inverse of this such that this.translate(this.inverse()) yields zero

unitVector

Euclidean unitVector()
Creates a unitVector of this, the unitVectors scale is determined by unitSize

Returns:
Returns this scaled to a unit vector

unitize

Euclidean unitize()
Categorizes each of the coordinates of this as positive, negative or zero.

This is NOT unitVector() and performs a completely different operation.

Returns:
Euclidean representing the sign value of this

average

static Euclidean average(java.util.Collection<Euclidean> c)
Averages a collection of Euclidean values and returns that average.

The collection c is not modified in any manner.

Parameters:
c - - Collecion<Euclidean> of values to average
Returns:
Average of all Euclideans in c

isAbout

boolean isAbout(Euclidean o)
Compares the coordinates of this with the coordinates of o. The comparison is +- Epsilon thus to return true all of the coordinates of this must be within Epsilon of the corresponding coordinate of o.

Parameters:
o - - Euclidean to compare this with
Returns:
True if the coordinates of this = the coordinates of o +- Epsilon.

False otherwise

isAbout

private boolean isAbout(java.lang.Double a,
                        java.lang.Double b)
Determines if a is within Epsilon of b.

Parameters:
a - - Double value
b - - Double value to compare to a
Returns:
True if a == b +- Epsilon

False else

See Also:
isAbout(Euclidean)

isBoundedBy

boolean isBoundedBy(Euclidean lb,
                    Euclidean ub)
Determines if this is bounded above and below by lb and ub. The bounds are not strict so lb could be the upper bound as long as ub is then the lower bound so if this returns true then lb and ub are guaranteed to bound this but which is the uppper and which is the lower bound is not known.

The bounds are within Epsilon error.

Parameters:
lb - - Euclidean forming lower bound
ub - - Euclidean forming upper bound
Returns:
True if this is bounded by lb and ub

False otherwise

See Also:
isTightBoundedBy(Euclidean, Euclidean)

isEpsilonBound

private boolean isEpsilonBound(java.lang.Double ub,
                               java.lang.Double val,
                               java.lang.Double lb)
Determines if val is bounded by ub and lb. The bounds are not strictly in that order so ub may be the lower bound but if that is so then lb must be the upper bound so if this returns true then val is bounded by ub and lb but which is the upper bound and which is the lower bound is unknown.

The bounds are within Epsilon precision.

Parameters:
ub - - Upper bound
val - - value to check if bounded
lb - - Lower bound
Returns:
True if val is bounded by ub and lb.

False otherwise

See Also:
isBoundedBy(Euclidean, Euclidean)

isTightBoundedBy

boolean isTightBoundedBy(Euclidean lb,
                         Euclidean ub)
Determines if val is bounded by ub and lb. The bounds are not strictly in that order so ub may be the lower bound but if that is so then lb must be the upper bound so if this returns true then val is bounded by ub and lb but which is the upper bound and which is the lower bound is unknown.

The bounds are exact and thus not influenced by Epsilon.

Parameters:
ub - - Upper bound
lb - - Lower bound
Returns:
True if val is bounded by ub and lb.

False otherwise

See Also:
isBoundedBy(Euclidean, Euclidean)

isBoundedBy

private boolean isBoundedBy(java.lang.Double lb,
                            java.lang.Double val,
                            java.lang.Double ub)
Determines if val is bounded by ub and lb. The bounds are not strictly in that order so ub may be the lower bound but if that is so then lb must be the upper bound so if this returns true then val is bounded by ub and lb but which is the upper bound and which is the lower bound is unknown.

The bounds are exact and thus not influenced by Epsilon.

Parameters:
ub - - Upper bound
val - - value to check if bounded
lb - - Lower bound
Returns:
True if val is bounded by ub and lb.

False otherwise

See Also:
isTightBoundedBy(Euclidean, Euclidean)
